We did an implementation similar to this.  We've also doen it with shortest
distance to output layer.  For the purpose of determining a best guess at
which links should be recurrent it has served us well.

For the purpose of determinnig a graphical layout, it's not quite as good.
Since we're using shortest distance, nodes tend to get "pulled" toward the
input or output layer.

> Message: 1
>    Date: Mon, 05 Apr 2004 01:11:37 -0000

> Subject: Re: Mat Buckland's method for determining Layers and Recurrency
>
> There is another way (very similar to described one):
> Each neuron will have a layer identificator and input neurons will always
be a 0 level. Then for each other neurons a shortest distance to the input
neurons is calculated. If, for instance, given neuron connected with input
one then it has layer index 1, or if given neuron connected with no input
neurons but with neurons with layer indices 2, 4, and 5 then its layer will
be 3 (minimum possible). Thus it's easy to determine for each connection
whether its recurrent or not. We're just need to substract finish neuron
layer index and start neurons layer index. If it's positive then connection
is direct, if not then we have a reccurent connection.
